awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Levels and Social Determinants of Nutritional Outcomes
awd_abstract_narration:
SES-1539804
Michael White
Vaidya Yashas 
Brown University

Shifts in diets, physical activity and nutritional outcomes are taking place across the world and are producing poor nutritional outcomes at different extremes.  That is, malnutrition and obesity might co-exist within a particular society. This dissertation research will collect body measurements and biomarker data to investigate whether outcomes on the extremes of nutritional spectrum co-exist together and at what units of analysis.  Specifically, the investigator will study nutritional and health outcomes and their causes at finer spatial scales and link these individual outcomes to household and background factors that contribute to health.  The project takes advantage of existing longitudinal data from the mid-1990s, and ongoing fieldwork that tracks demographic and social changes. This project will also looks at early-life and other influences on health. Thus, prospective and retrospective data will be analyzed to determine early-life factors that might affect current nutritional outcomes. The literature on the nutrition transition has focused on trends at the country or region-level. The dual burden of undernutrition and over nutrition is one feature of this nutritional transition. 

Lower and Middle Income (LMICs) countries are now also experiencing spatial and urban transformations, changes in food production, globalization and increasing social inequalities that are pinpointed as factors responsible for shifts in nutritional outcomes and towards increased diet-related Non-communicable Diseases (NCDs). The social, and not necessarily economic, roots of this shift has allowed "epidemics" of over nutrition and related chronic NCDs to extend beyond high-income countries to those usually classified as developing countries. The public-health- interpretation often presents a linear theory of this societal transformation. This project takes a sociologically informed view, which recognizes that the social processes driving these shifts are unevenly distributed. It focuses more on the micro processes within the community and household that might result in heterogeneous consequences like extreme nutritional outcomes, now referred to as the dual burden. This dual burden phenomenon allows a possibility where undernutrition and over nutrition might represent different facets of deprivation. The high and continued prevalence of undernutrition at early ages does not negate the possibility of later-life problems of over nutrition. The related burden of NCDs for South Asia, the region being studied, has risen at a rate exceeding global rates. The dual nutritional status burden examined in this project has a potential impact on national healthcare policy, international aid objectives and more. Thus, the detection and determinants of such a dual burden is a concern for both individuals and communities.  The study builds on collaboration with an existing research site in Nepal, the Chitwan Valley Family Study (CVFS).

Project Summary

This project examines social factors that affect nutrition in low- and middle- income countries (LMICs) through original data collection. Many countries in South Asia, Sub-Saharan Africa and Latin America still suffer high rates of undernutrition, despite biomedical, economic and technical advancements. While data sources are expanding quickly, not many of them contain information at various levels of analysis for the same period--say, on individuals, families, neighborhoods and communities together. Similarly, not many of them capture conditions at different points in time, especially from the past. To explore these connections, this project adds a household survey at a research site in Nepal to collect data on nutritional outcomes among children (ages 5-10). Then it matches these present-day outcomes with existing information on families and households collected over two decades at the study site as well as historical data on the neighborhoods. Building these multi-level datasets, the project explores what factors influence outcomes at various levels of analysis--say, for individuals and for neighborhoods. For example, using statistical analyses, the study finds that contextual factors such as neighborhood age and location affect present-day nutritional outcomes for children.

Research Outcomes

The project build builds on research at the Chitwan Valley Family Study (CVFS). The team, based in the Institute of Social Research (ISR) at University of Michigan and at the site in Nepal, has over 20 years of experience collecting high-quality data for demographic and social science research. Their data sources include, among others, “full life histories for more than 10,000 individuals, tracking and interviews with all migrants, continuous measurement of community change, 16 years of demographic event registry, and linked human and natural systems.” More details can be found on the institute’s website: spe.psc.isr.umich.edu/research/cvfs.html. The project partnered with CVFS research staff on new data collection efforts and subsequent analysis. It is one of the first to collect data on nutritional outcomes at the site. As the CVFS moves towards newer topics of research, the project played a part in the study site’s evolution toward studies of health outcomes. In addition, the project also supported the co-Principal Investigator’s dissertation research at Brown University. 

Intellectual Outcomes

The primary intellectual outcomes of this project are a PhD dissertation and related academic papers. One of these papers uses six decades of data from 1955 to present-day Chitwan on human settlements and health facilities to address issues in urban sociology and spatial demography. In LMIC settings, most research looks at a place’s transition from rural to urban. Yet this distinction is usually one based on administrative classifications. Change over time remains unexplored in detail, since traditional sources of geographic data like statistical records, satellite images and maps are hard to find. The paper addresses this knowledge gap using historic data from CVFS records. Neighborhoods, within which individuals and households are enmeshed, are themselves shown to be structured through space and time. Statistical analysis shows that there is a temporal and spatial hierarchy that influences how neighborhoods change. Thus, this paper adds to the limited knowledge on urban transformations in LMIC settings.

Another paper looks at spatial and social inequalities in health outcomes in LMICs. Such discussions are quite advanced in high-income settings, for example, around racial disparities in U.S. health outcomes. In comparison, work on residential patterns and segregation and their effects is only beginning in LMICs. This paper shows that social and spatial structures are interlinked in the production of health outcomes. In this setting, ethnicity is a complex marker of social hierarchy. The paper shows that it has an influence on health outcomes, going beyond the socio-economic status (SES) of households, i.e. ethnic disparities are not simply the result of differences in SES. Overall, the project adds to the analysis of nutritional outcomes in a region undergoing rapid urban transformations. The results are also likely to contribute to public health discussions about the nutrition transition in LMICs.
